text: I mentioned in my email the other day that I'd be sharing some recent books on startups and investing. Here are a couple that I've read recently that I've enjoyed.

attachments.text: Amazon Zero to One: Notes on Startups, or How to Build the Future
attachments.fallback: Amazon Zero to One: Notes on Startups, or How to Build the Future

attachments.text: The Hard Thing About Hard Things: Building a Business When There Are No Easy Answers [Ben Horowitz] on <http://Amazon.com|Amazon.com>. *FREE* shipping on qualifying offers. Ben Horowitz, cofounder of Andreessen Horowitz and one of Silicon Valley's most respected and experienced entrepreneurs
attachments.fallback: The Hard Thing About Hard Things: Building a Business When There Are No Easy Answers [Ben Horowitz] on <http://Amazon.com|Amazon.com>. *FREE* shipping on qualifying offers. Ben Horowitz, cofounder of Andreessen Horowitz and one of Silicon Valley's most respected and experienced entrepreneurs

text: Both are really good reads and fairly quick.
The Horowitz book is more about building and managing teams. Thiel's book is about finding outlier companies to invest in.
And last but not least, I just started reading this:

attachments.text: Amazon The Responsive City: Engaging Communities Through Data-Smart Governance
attachments.fallback: Amazon The Responsive City: Engaging Communities Through Data-Smart Governance

text: It's a little slow. Not sure if I'd recommend it yet.
